stories.title: Andrej Karpathy: Software in the era of AI [video]
stories.author: sandslash
stories.article_summary: Article content too short to summarize effectively.

main_themes: Gemini, introduced as a chatbot for documentation, failed to accurately represent company information, demonstrating the risks of relying on AI tools that may not meet basic operational standards.
The trend towards integrating AI in business operations is evident, but the frequent failures of these tools highlight a gap that needs addressing for broader adoption.
agreement_points: There is a consensus that current AI tools are often brittle and unreliable, as evidenced by multiple users sharing experiences of flawed outputs.
disagreement_points: Debate exists around whether AI tools will ever achieve the reliability needed for professional use, with some believing improvements are possible while others remain skeptical.
comments_analysis.sentiment_summary: The discussion reflects a growing frustration within the community regarding the reliability of AI tools like Claude 4 and Gemini. Users report significant issues such as hallucinations and incorrect outputs, which undermine their utility in professional settings. There is a shared concern about the brittleness of these systems and whether they can ever achieve the reliability needed for widespread adoption. The community is divided on the future of AI reliability, with some expressing hope for improvements while others remain skeptical.
comments_analysis.top_comment_summary: The commenter highlights the limitations of AI systems like Claude 4 in practical applications, noting that despite prompting for accuracy, it still produced inefficient code. They emphasize the gap between the idealized capabilities of AI and the complexities of real-world software engineering.

specific_numbers: Claude 4's inability to handle EXIF data efficiently highlights the limitations of current AI models in practical applications, emphasizing the need for better optimization in image processing tasks.
tools_mentioned: Gemini, introduced as a chatbot for documentation, failed to accurately represent company information, demonstrating the risks of relying on AI tools that may not meet basic operational standards.
performance_data: The performance of AI models like Claude 4 and Gemini is currently hindered by issues such as hallucinations and incorrect outputs, which can lead to user frustration and decreased productivity.

resource_requirements: The need for accurate AI tools in documentation processes is critical; without reliable models, companies risk wasting time and resources on flawed outputs.

compatibility_issues: AI tools like Gemini may fail to integrate smoothly with existing documentation systems, leading to potential operational disruptions if not properly configured.

strong_agreements: There is a consensus that current AI tools are often brittle and unreliable, as evidenced by multiple users sharing experiences of flawed outputs.
major_disagreements: Debate exists around whether AI tools will ever achieve the reliability needed for professional use, with some believing improvements are possible while others remain skeptical.

market_trends: The trend towards integrating AI in business operations is evident, but the frequent failures of these tools highlight a gap that needs addressing for broader adoption.
competitive_landscape: The competitive landscape for AI tools is shifting, with companies needing to innovate rapidly to avoid falling behind due to the unreliability of current offerings.

failed_attempts: Attempts to use AI models like Claude 4 and Gemini in real-world applications have often resulted in failures, underscoring the need for more robust solutions.

actionable_advice: Companies should thoroughly vet AI tools before implementation to ensure they meet basic operational needs, which can prevent wasted resources and frustration.
what_to_avoid: Avoid relying solely on AI for critical tasks without human oversight, as this can lead to significant errors and operational inefficiencies.

top_comments.author: mentalgear
top_comments.text:
Meanwhile, I asked this morning Claude 4 to write a simple EXIF normalizer. After two rounds of prompting it to double-check its code, I still had to point out that it makes no sense to load the entire image for re-orientating if the EXIF orientation is fine in the first place.
Vibe vs reality, and anyone actually working in the space daily can attest how brittle these systems are.
Maybe this changes in SWE with more automated tests in verifiable simulators, but the real world is far to complex to simulate in its vastness.

top_comments.author: ApeWithCompiler
top_comments.text:
A manager in our company introduced Gemini as a chat bot coupled to our documentation.
> It failed to write out our company name.The rest was flawed with hallucinations also, hardly worth to mention.
I wish this is a rage bait towards others, but what should me feelings be? After all this is the tool thats sold to me, I am expected to work with.

top_comments.author: diggan
top_comments.text:
> Meanwhile
What do you mean "meanwhile", that's exactly (among other things) the kind of stuff he's talking about? The various frictions and how you need to approach it

top_comments.author: coreyh14444
top_comments.text: https://theeducationist.info/everything-amazing-nobody-happy...

top_comments.author: ramon156
top_comments.text: The real question is how long it'll take until they're not brittle

top_comments.author: kubb
top_comments.text: Or will they ever be reliable. Your question is already making an assumption.

top_comments.author: fergie
top_comments.text:
There were some cool ideas- I particularly liked "psychology of AI"
Overall though I really feel like he is selling the idea that we are going to have to pay large corporations to be able to write code. Which is... terrifying.
Also, as a lazy developer who is always trying to make AI do my job for me, it still kind of sucks, and its not clear that it will make my life easier any time soon.

top_comments.author: teekert
top_comments.text:
He says that now we are in the mainframe phase. We will hit the personal computing phase hopefully soon. He says llama (and DeepSeek?) are like Linux in a way, OpenAI and Claude are like Windows and MacOS.
So, No, he’s actually saying it may be everywhere for cheap soon.
I find the talk to be refreshingly intellectually honest and unbiased. Like the opposite of a cringey LinkedIn post on AI.

top_comments.author: guappa
top_comments.text:
I think it used to be like that before the GNU people made gcc, completely destroying the market of compilers.
> Also, as a lazy developer who is always trying to make AI do my job for me, it still kind of sucks, and its not clear that it will make my life easier any time soon.
Every time I have to write a simple self contained couple of functions I try… and it gets it completely wrong.
It's easier to just write it myself rather than to iterate 50 times and hope it will work, considering iterations are also very slow.

stories.title: Show HN: Claude Code Usage Monitor – real-time tracker to dodge usage cut-offs
stories.author: Maciej-roboblog
stories.article_summary: The Claude Code Usage Monitor is a real-time terminal tool designed for tracking Claude AI token usage, offering features such as updates every 3 seconds, visual progress bars, and smart predictions for token depletion based on current burn rates. It supports multiple plans—Pro (~7,000 tokens), Max5 (~35,000), and Max20 (~140,000)—and includes an auto-detection mode that switches to a custom limit when the Pro threshold is exceeded. Users can customize reset times and time zones, with default reset times set for every 5 hours after the first message in a session. The tool can be installed using Python 3.6+ and npm, with a simple command like `./ccusage_monitor.py --plan pro` for basic usage. As stated in the article, "Start Early: Begin monitoring when you start a new session" is a key actionable insight for effective management of token usage.

main_themes: uv tool: This tool allows for the installation of Python and Node tools in a self-contained manner, preventing duplication and maintaining system integrity, which is crucial for developers managing multiple projects.
agreement_points: There is a consensus that using uv tool prevents unnecessary duplication of Python installations, which is seen as a significant improvement in managing development environments.

There is a shared concern about the fragility of global Node installations, emphasizing the need for careful version management to avoid disruptions in development workflows.

stories.title: From LLM to AI Agent: What's the Real Journey Behind AI System Development?
stories.author: codelink
stories.article_summary: The article discusses the evolution of AI systems, particularly focusing on Large Language Models (LLMs), Retrieval Augmented Generation (RAG), AI workflows, and AI agents. It emphasizes that while AI agents offer autonomy, simpler solutions often suffice for many applications, such as a resume-screening tool. For instance, an LLM can classify resumes as "Passed" or "Failed" using one-shot prompting, while RAG enhances this by integrating internal data for improved decision-making. Key insights include starting with simple workflows and only adopting AI agents when necessary, as well as prioritizing reliability over capability in production systems. Notably, the article suggests employing APIs for automation, such as connecting to email and calendar services to streamline recruitment processes.

market_signals.description: Increased use of LLMs for simple tasks like resume screening.

business_opportunities.description: Develop LLM-based tools for HR processes like resume screening.

competitive_intelligence.strategic_moves: Focus on reliability over complexity in AI solutions.
competitive_intelligence.market_impact: Shift towards simpler, more reliable AI applications.

investment_insights.investment_angle: Growing demand for AI in HR tech solutions.
investment_insights.risk_factors: Over-reliance on complex AI agents may lead to failures.
investment_insights.potential_returns: High potential in the next 1-2 years as adoption grows.

actionable_takeaways: Invest in developing LLM tools for recruitment.
Create APIs to integrate AI into existing HR systems.

key_metrics.growth_indicators: Increased adoption of AI in recruitment processes.
key_metrics.market_size: HR tech market projected to grow significantly.

stories.title: TI to invest $60B to manufacture foundational semiconductors in the U.S.
stories.author: TMWNN
stories.article_summary: Texas Instruments (TI) has announced a historic investment of over $60 billion to expand semiconductor manufacturing in the U.S., marking the largest such investment in the nation's history. This initiative includes the construction of seven semiconductor fabs across mega-sites in Texas and Utah, which will create over 60,000 jobs. TI's Sherman site alone will see up to $40 billion allocated for four fabs (SM1, SM2, SM3, and SM4), with SM1 and SM2 already in progress. CEO Haviv Ilan stated, “TI is building dependable, low-cost 300mm capacity at scale,” emphasizing the critical role these chips play in various sectors, from automotive to healthcare. Partnerships with leading companies such as Apple, Ford, Medtronic, NVIDIA, and SpaceX highlight TI's commitment to driving innovation in American manufacturing and technology.

top_comments.author: ryukoposting
top_comments.text: I find that the easiest way to suss out corporate political advertisements is to look for how they refer to the federal government. If they say "federal government" or "$NAME_OF_ACT" then there's usually at least an inkling of intent behind whatever they say next. If they say "$PRESIDENT administration" or "$PARTY_NAME," you can be certain you're reading a political advertisement.

stories.title: Six-month-old, solo-owned vibe coder Base44 sells to Wix for $80M cash
stories.author: myth_drannon
stories.article_summary: Israeli developer Maor Shlomo's vibe-coding startup, Base44, was acquired by Wix for $80 million just six months after its launch. Despite being a bootstrapped venture, Base44 rapidly grew to 250,000 users, generating $189,000 in profit by May, largely through word-of-mouth and Shlomo's social media presence. The platform enables users to create applications without coding by utilizing text prompts and supports various integrations, including email and analytics. Shlomo attributed the sale to the need for scaling beyond organic growth, stating, "the scale and volume we need is not something we can organically grow into," highlighting the potential of AI in startup productivity.

Commenters highlight the impressive nature of achieving an $80M valuation in just six months, contrasting it with the typical struggles of startups to reach similar milestones. However, there is also a debate about the implications of the term 'solo-owned' when an eight-person team is involved, suggesting a nuanced view of ownership and team dynamics in startup success.

stories.title: Bento: A Steam Deck in a Keyboard
stories.author: MichaelThatsIt
stories.article_summary: Bento is an innovative, compact computer designed to work seamlessly with external spatial displays, such as the XREAL One, and is inspired by the design of the Commodore 64. It utilizes the main board, cooler, and battery from a Steam Deck OLED, emphasizing portability by eliminating built-in displays and unnecessary weight. The creator expresses frustration with current XR hardware, stating, "the dominant players... promote their hardware as 'computers,' when really they’re an iPad for your face," advocating for a true "spatial computer." The project is open-sourced, with available files for 3D printing and a request for contributions on supporting various keyboards and single-board computers (SBCs), including a Raspberry Pi 5 variant.

main_themes: XREAL glasses are discussed for their use in spatial displays, which are essential for immersive experiences but may not be suitable for all tasks, impacting user choice.
The trend towards integrating XR technology in everyday devices is growing, as evidenced by user interest in compact designs that enhance portability, indicating a shift in consumer preferences.

disagreement_points: There is debate over the suitability of XR glasses for work versus entertainment, with some users finding them adequate for gaming but lacking for productivity tasks, highlighting differing user needs.

Users generally prefer the XREAL One Pros over the Air glasses due to their superior performance, although there are concerns about eye fatigue and suitability for work tasks. The community is divided on the effectiveness of XR devices for professional use, indicating a need for further advancements in the technology to meet diverse user needs.

top_comments.author: MichaelThatsIt
top_comments.text:
This is a project that had been eating away at me for a bit, sitting in the back of my mind.
It's a computer that fit's perfectly underneath an Apple Magic Keyboard, and has a compartment to store peripherals like a dongle or small mouse. It has no display, instead opting for XR display glasses.
The internals are the main board, cooler, and battery from a Steam Deck OLED. I bought the parts separately rather than gutting a perfectly good one.
The link is to the CAD files. I decided to open source it as I explore building a better one.
Feel free to jump straight to that, here's the origin story for anyone interested:
I started using the XREAL glasses a few months ago. they're great, easily my favorite "XR" product. It's built around the one killer app of XR, a virtual display. shedding all non-essential hardware into a small, lightweight package.
but I hate the redundancy. Whatever device I'm using it with, the built in screen goes unused. In parallel, I've also found myself extremely disappointed in each product calling itself a "spatial computer" despite being nothing but an overweight iPad for your face.
I wanted a real computer designed to be used with these glasses, and in the smallest package I could possibly achieve.
So I grabbed an actual iPad, downloaded Shapr3D and got to work. My iteration process involved jumping back and forth between my iPad and a 3D printer. I went through roughly 15 failed iterations getting the screw mounts, airflow, and ergonomics just right.
The final result is what I believe to be a true spatial computer. I've been daily driving and I'm pretty happy with the experience. It's currently running Ubuntu 24, but I may switch back to Steam OS, given it's better optimized for the hardware.

top_comments.author: marci
top_comments.text:
Instead of carrying a small mouse, the case itself could be a trackpad :D
https://ploopy.co/trackpad/

top_comments.author: ludicrousdispla
top_comments.text: You should put at least the first three sentences from your comment into the project's readme.md file as I had no idea what a 'spatial display' or XREAL is for that matter.

top_comments.author: nottorp
top_comments.text:
> I started using the XREAL glasses a few months ago.
How's your eye sight? Any signs of fatigue?
I've seen people saying that they're fine for gaming and movie watching but too fuzzy for work...

top_comments.author: regularfry
top_comments.text: The Air glasses are a bit fuzzy. The Xreal One Pros are far better. I can work all day in them, if I'm not going to be on any video calls.

top_comments.author: MichaelThatsIt
top_comments.text: No more than any other XR product. I can do the work I need to from it for the most part.

top_comments.author: nottorp
top_comments.text: I’m asking AR vs monitors, not comparisons between AR products.

top_comments.author: zavec
top_comments.text:
This looks awesome!
> I bought the parts separately rather than gutting a perfectly good one.
Huh, I didn't know you could do that. Neat.

top_comments.author: ezschemi
top_comments.text: Thank you very much for sharing the files and your experience! I just got my first XR glasses, Xreal One Pro, and had your link bookmarked to do something similar. I am very impressed with these glasses. Looking through ifixit I can't find the Steam Deck's mainboard. Where did you find it?

top_comments.author: MichaelThatsIt
top_comments.text:
Ebay! But fear not! I’m working on a version based on the Radxa Rock 5B which is more readily available and has more kick than a pi 5.
Also doing the research on productizing the whole thing and sourcing a custom board.

stories.title: Fang, the CLI Starter Kit
stories.author: bewuethr
stories.article_summary: Fang is an experimental CLI starter kit designed for Cobra applications, offering features such as fully styled help pages, error messages, and automatic versioning. It includes a hidden command for generating manpages using Mango, which enhances the appearance of documentation by utilizing roff instead of markdown. The library allows for customizable themes, supports silent usage output to improve user experience, and is easy to implement with a simple invocation of `fang.Execute` alongside a Cobra command. As part of the Charm ecosystem, Fang is open-source under the MIT license, inviting community feedback and contributions via platforms like Twitter and Discord.

main_themes: Goreleaser is a tool that simplifies the release process for Go applications by creating GitHub releases, Homebrew packages, Docker images, and Linux packages, which streamlines deployment and reduces manual errors.
agreement_points: The community agrees that cross-compiling in Rust is significantly more complex than in Go, primarily due to Rust's reliance on dynamic linking, which complicates the build process.
comments_analysis.sentiment_summary: The discussion highlights the complexities of cross-compiling in Rust compared to Go, with community members emphasizing the ease of Go's static linking versus Rust's dynamic linking challenges. Tools like Goreleaser are praised for their ability to streamline the release process in Go, showcasing a preference for efficient deployment solutions in the developer community.
comments_analysis.top_comment_summary: The commenter highlights the challenges of cross-compiling for CLI applications, noting that unlike web back-ends where the execution environment is controlled, CLIs must accommodate multiple operating systems, complicating the development process.

tools_mentioned: Goreleaser is a tool that simplifies the release process for Go applications by creating GitHub releases, Homebrew packages, Docker images, and Linux packages, which streamlines deployment and reduces manual errors.

setup_instructions: Setting the environment variables $GOOS and $GOARCH is crucial for cross-compiling in Go, as it allows developers to target different operating systems and architectures, and skipping this step can lead to failed builds.
compatibility_issues: Rust's dynamic linking can cause compatibility issues when cross-compiling, as it requires system libraries that may not be available on the target system, making it essential to ensure the correct libraries are included.

strong_agreements: The community agrees that cross-compiling in Rust is significantly more complex than in Go, primarily due to Rust's reliance on dynamic linking, which complicates the build process.
expert_opinions: Carlos, the creator of GoReleaser, is recognized for his contributions to the Go ecosystem, which highlights the importance of having robust tools for managing software releases in modern development.

actionable_advice: Developers should consider using Goreleaser for their Go projects to automate the release process, which can save time and reduce the potential for errors during deployment.

top_comments.author: csomar
top_comments.text:
I’ve been maintaining rust-starter[!] for quite sometime now. It is kind of the equivalent of fang but for Rust. It uses Clap which is the equivalent of Cobra; though I don’t think Clap has the same kind of fancy output?
Throughout these years, I have found that cross-compiling is the most challenging part of creating a CLI. When you are building a web back-end, you control the execution environment (usually linux). For CLIs, your users could be on Linux, macOS or Windows. You need to get three x2 binaries (so a total of 6) to have a fair coverage.
I’ve tried cross, but for Windows and macOS you need licenses. There is no straightforward way to give your users Docker images and have them running in a few commands. You can compile on GitHub action machines, but that’s a very slow feedback loop. I wonder if things are better in Go land.
!: https://github.com/rust-starter/rust-starter

top_comments.author: neomantra
top_comments.text:
Golang itself bundles a toolchain and can cross compile to a many target OSes and architectures. I use Goreleaser [1] to create GitHub releases, Homebrew packages, Docker images, and Linux packages. Goreleaser Pro can also create MSI packages.
ETA since I just saw Christian chime in: the Goreleaser author works at Charm.sh =)
[1] https://goreleaser.com

top_comments.author: christianrocha
top_comments.text:
GoReleaser is indeed an awesome tool and we use it for every applicable project.
And actually Carlos, who builds GoReleaser, is the true author of Fang and took it from concept to execution.

top_comments.author: threemux
top_comments.text: Wow TIL cross compilation is a bit of a pain in Rust. I assumed it was as easy as Go. I can confirm as long as you're using pure Go (no cgo), it's as easy as setting $GOOS and $GOARCH appropriately.

top_comments.author: paulddraper
top_comments.text:
The difficulty is due to Rust dynamically linking and Go statically linking. The former requires the system libs.
That said, I am unfamiliar with any licensing for Windows builds.
MacOS has some niche (usually discarded) technicalities like you can only use the SDK on Apple hardware.

top_comments.author: threemux
top_comments.text: I think that's a reference to the use of Docker in the "cross" tool that makes cross compilation easier but I'm not certain

top_comments.author: christianrocha
top_comments.text:
I feel your pain. That said, cross compiling from Go is pretty trivial, as long as everything is pure Go, which it most often is. That’s one if the reasons we invested in jt.
(Hello from Charm! I’m one of the authors of this library.)

top_comments.author: mootoday
top_comments.text:
This is great, lots I learned by looking at your code and the dependencies you use!
I started a similar thing, although not as feature-rich as yours. My goal was to follow CLI best practices and add all the boilerplate one needs to build a Rust CLI.
https://github.com/mootoday/cli-template

top_comments.author: rmac
top_comments.text:
I looked into how rust does does it for rustup, and they have a pretty amazing set of gh actions to build for their architectures, I can't find the GH link now tho
for speed you can look for vendors like https://depot.dev/

top_comments.author: johnisgood
top_comments.text:
I just ran across "gum"[1] from charmbracelet which I intend to use! I just want to replace dialog. I came across whiptail, too, but gum seems nicer.
They have a TUI framework, too, among a lot of other related things. Some of their projects are Go libraries, some are a CLI tool, such as gum.
[1] https://github.com/charmbracelet/gum

stories.title: Writing documentation for AI: best practices
stories.author: mooreds
stories.article_summary: The article emphasizes the importance of high-quality documentation for AI systems, particularly Retrieval-Augmented Generation (RAG) frameworks like Kapa, which relies on well-structured content to generate accurate responses. Key components include a retriever that searches documentation, a vector database for storage, and a generator (LLM) that formulates answers. It underscores that "poor documentation doesn't just frustrate human readers; it directly degrades the quality of AI responses," highlighting the necessity for explicit and self-contained content chunks to improve AI accuracy. Actionable insights include using standardized semantic HTML, avoiding PDFs in favor of HTML or Markdown, and ensuring semantic clarity in URLs, which collectively enhance machine readability and retrieval efficiency.

main_themes: SEO practices are discussed in relation to HTML structure and accessibility, which are critical for improving website visibility and user experience, ultimately affecting traffic and engagement.
The trend towards AI-friendly documentation reflects a broader shift in the industry towards automation and efficiency, which can enhance competitiveness.
agreement_points: There is a consensus that good documentation and coding practices lead to better software quality, which is supported by the experiences shared by developers in the comments.
comments_analysis.sentiment_summary: The discussion emphasizes the importance of good documentation and coding practices, with community members agreeing that these practices enhance software usability and efficiency. The comments reflect a realization that effective documentation is not just about making it AI-friendly but about adhering to fundamental principles that benefit users. Additionally, there is a recognition that while SEO techniques can improve visibility, they should not compromise content quality, as this can lead to negative user experiences.
comments_analysis.top_comment_summary: The commenter highlights the irony that creating AI-friendly documentation aligns closely with the principles of effective documentation, such as clear context, structured hierarchy, and precise error messages. Essentially, good documentation naturally lends itself to being AI-friendly.

specific_numbers: The emphasis on good documentation practices highlights that effective documentation is essential for user understanding and software usability, which can lead to reduced support costs and improved user satisfaction.
tools_mentioned: SEO practices are discussed in relation to HTML structure and accessibility, which are critical for improving website visibility and user experience, ultimately affecting traffic and engagement.
performance_data: The mention of SEO slop garbage indicates that while there are techniques to improve search rankings, the lack of meaningful content can lead to poor user engagement, which is detrimental for long-term success.

resource_requirements: Effective documentation and SEO require skilled personnel and time investment; without these resources, companies may struggle with user retention and visibility.
efficiency_gains: By adopting standard software engineering practices, developers can streamline their coding process, leading to faster development cycles and reduced time spent on debugging.

strong_agreements: There is a consensus that good documentation and coding practices lead to better software quality, which is supported by the experiences shared by developers in the comments.

market_trends: The trend towards AI-friendly documentation reflects a broader shift in the industry towards automation and efficiency, which can enhance competitiveness.

working_setups: Developers report that structuring code logically allows for easier problem-solving and maintenance, which can lead to significant time savings in development.

actionable_advice: Invest in training for good documentation and coding practices to improve software quality and team efficiency, leading to better project outcomes.
what_to_avoid: Avoid prioritizing SEO tricks over meaningful content, as this can lead to short-term gains but long-term user disengagement.

top_comments.author: emil_sorensen
top_comments.text: OP here. It's kind of ironic that making the docs AI-friendly essentially just ends up being what good documentation is in the first place (explicit context and hierarchy, self-contained sections, precise error messages).

top_comments.author: shafyy
top_comments.text: It's the same for SEO also. Good structure, correct use of HTML elements, quick loading, good accessibility, etc. Sure, there are "tricks" to improve your SEO, but the general principles are also good if you were not doing SEO.

top_comments.author: klysm
top_comments.text: And yet in practice SEO slop garbage is SEO slop garbage. Devoid of any real meaning or purpose other than to increase rankings and metrics. Nobody cares if it’s good or useful, but it must appease the algorithm!

top_comments.author: jilles
top_comments.text: It's similar for writing code. Suddenly people are articulating their problems to the LLM and breaking it down in smaller sub-problems to solve....

top_comments.author: arscan
top_comments.text: In other words, people are discovering the value of standard software engineering practices. Which, I think is a good thing.

top_comments.author: corysama
top_comments.text: It has changed how I structure my code. Out of laziness, if I can write the code in such a way that each step follows naturally from what came before, "the code just writes itself!" Except now it's literally true :D

top_comments.author: appreciatorBus
top_comments.text: Maybe everyone already discovered this but I find that if I include a lot of detail in my variables names, it's much more likely to autocomplete something useful. If whatever I typed was too verbose for my liking long term, I can always clean it up later with a rename.

top_comments.author: bobbiechen
top_comments.text:
Related: "If an AI agent can't figure out how your API works, neither can your users" (from my employer's blog)
https://stytch.com/blog/if-an-ai-agent-cant-figure-out-how-y...

top_comments.author: Cthulhu_
top_comments.text:
It's a good tool to use for code reviewing, especially if you don't have peers with Strong Opinions on it.
Which is another issue, indifference. It's hard to find people that actually care about things like API design, let alone multiple that check each other's work. In my experience, a lot of the time people just get lazy and short-circuit the reviews to "oh he knows what he's doing, I'm sure he thought long and hard about this".

top_comments.author: thom
top_comments.text: Yeah, I've started to think AI smoke tests for cognitive complexity should be a fundamental part of API/schema design now. Even if you think the LLMs are dumb, Stupidity as a Service is genuinely useful.
